title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
A large group of senior Wall Street executives, including David Solomon of Goldman Sachs and Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone, have backed Joe Biden's $1.9tn stimulus plan ahead of this week's crucial votes on the package in Congress.

In a letter to congressional leaders from both parties yesterday, more than 150 business leaders based in New York City called for “immediate and large-scale federal legislation” to tackle the fallout from the pandemic.

“Previous federal relief measures have been essential, but more must be done to put the country on a trajectory for a strong, durable recovery,” they wrote.

The support for Biden's plan from some of the top names in the US financial sector — who also include Larry Fink of BlackRock and Ken Jacobs of Lazard — comes despite strong opposition from Republicans on Capitol Hill who believe the level of new spending is excessive.

Meanwhile Jay Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, has switched to a more neutral stance on fiscal support after vocally advocating it last year. During two days of questioning from lawmakers on Capitol Hill this week, Powell repeatedly refused to take a position on Biden's stimulus package — though he dismissed concerns that it might lead to an unwanted jump in inflation this year.

Coronavirus digest

  • The US FDA confirmed Johnson & Johnson's single-shot vaccine was safe and effective. It could receive emergency use authorisation as soon as this weekend.

  • Moderna has become the first vaccine maker to produce a shot targeted at the virus variant discovered in South Africa.

  • Germany, France and other EU countries are under pressure to expand vaccination efforts after Nordic frontrunners' success at deploying jabs.

  • Israel, which begins a holiday weekend curfew on Thursday, will send excess vaccines abroad, even as Palestinians wait for aid shipments of doses.

  • India's vaccine rollout struggles are reminiscent of the socialist “Licence Raj”, when New Delhi relaxed control of economic life but basic amenities were in short supply, writes Amy Kazmin.

  • Ghana has become the first country in the world to receive vaccines under the WHO-backed Covax facility for low-income countries. (FT, Times of Israel) 

Why have global Covid-19 infections plummeted? The drop has raised hopes but masks signs of a resurgence in parts of Europe. Follow our live blog for the latest.

In the news

Biden orders review of foreign supply chains Joe Biden has signed an executive order requiring federal agencies to conduct 100-day reviews of supply chains for semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, electric vehicle batteries and critical minerals used in manufacturing products such as cars and weapons. The move comes as the White House rushes to address a critical shortage in semiconductors for the car industry. (FT)

GameStop shares double The video game retailer's shares doubled in the final 90 minutes of trading on Wednesday, and had to be halted twice during the trading day. The clearing house at the centre of the GameStop trading frenzy proposed cutting the time to settle share deals after broker Robinhood complained that the two-day process was central to its decision to restrict some share trading. (FT)

McKinsey's Kevin Sneader voted out McKinsey partners voted to replace Kevin Sneader as global managing partner in a historic rebuke of his handling of a string of crises, including US litigation over the consultancy's advice to opioid manufacturers, according to several people with direct knowledge of the matter. The vote means McKinsey's next chief will be either Bob Sternfels or Sven Smit. (FT)

Xi asserts success of China's anti-poverty drive Chinese president Xi Jinping has claimed personal responsibility for eradicating poverty in China. The statement, made during a ceremony in Beijing, marks Xi's attempt to assert his position as one of the country's epoch-defining leaders, ahead of the centenary of the founding of the Chinese Communist party in July. (FT)

Anglo American cautious on higher commodity prices Anglo American chief executive Mark Cutifani said the global miner would not be “seduced” by rising commodity prices and splurge cash on deals or new projects after reporting its highest second-half profit since 2011. The industry is enjoying some of its most favourable conditions since rapid industrialisation of China's economy in the early 2000s. (FT)

Warning over stock market ‘clean-out' The world's big central banks are fuelling a bubble in technology stocks that will lead to a “clean-out” on global equity markets, Peter Costello, chairman of Australia's sovereign wealth fund, warned. (FT)

“What worries me is having expended all of their firepower there is not much left for the next crisis, and there will be another crisis.”

Sunak plans corporate tax increase UK chancellor Rishi Sunak will use the election of Joe Biden as partial cover for a big increase in corporation tax rates when he unveils his annual Budget next week. UK government officials note Biden has proposed an increase in corporate tax rates from 21 per cent to 28 per cent — a move that would give Sunak greater scope to push the UK rate up from its current 19 per cent. (FT)

Australia passes Big Tech law Australia's parliament has enacted a contentious law aimed at forcing Big Tech to pay for news content, in a move that could encourage other countries to pass similar legislation. The “world-first” regulation has forced Facebook and Google to strike licensing deals with news publishers. Regulation must address the way digital groups are reshaping our society, writes Robert Shrimsley. (FT)

UK spy agency to use AI GCHQ is preparing to use artificial intelligence to combat cyber attacks, identify state-backed disinformation and track criminal networks around the globe, according to an announcement on Wednesday.

  • GCHQ chief Jeremy Fleming argues that digital innovation has strategic and economic advantages but can be used for ill as well as good. (FT)

The days ahead

EU summit Vaccination passports that could allow leisure and business travel after inoculations will be discussed at a two-day EU leaders' summit that begins today. (FT)

Mitsubishi board meeting Mitsubishi Motors will formally consider reversing its decision to withdraw from Europe as it faces pressure from alliance partners Renault and Nissan. (FT)

Earnings round-up Companies reporting earnings include Airbnb, American Electric Power, Beyond Meat, Dell, DoorDash, Etsy, Moderna, Salesforce and Vale. (FT)

Economic data US weekly initial jobless claims, plus second estimates of fourth-quarter GDP and consumer spending.

What else we're reading

Big Tech must fight against AI bias In the 2010s, American political scientist Virginia Eubanks warned of the danger of artificial intelligence to poor communities. Her urgings received scant public attention then, but AI bias is triggering angry debate in Silicon Valley, writes Gillian Tett. (FT)

Lucid takes on Tesla Two years ago, Elon Musk claimed there was no battery car that could compete with Tesla's Model S. At the time, it was true. But now, Lucid Motors says the wait for a model to match the electric vehicle leader's specs is almost over. A boxy compact electric vehicle, starting at just $4,460, could also pose a threat by winning over Chinese buyers. (FT, Nikkei)

Belarus's digital revolution When president Alexander Lukashenko cracked down on those disputing his claim to have won a flawed election and imposed an internet blackout, Nexta — a media upstart using Telegram — stepped into the fray to challenge his autocratic regime. (FT)

The Senate power broker on Biden's speed dial Joe Biden may be the US president but another Joe from the Democratic party is fast emerging as the most powerful man in Washington, writes Lauren Fedor. Joe Manchin, the senior senator from West Virginia, is the most conservative member of his caucus and has a propensity to cross party lines — making him a figure to court in a Senate that the Democrats hold by the narrowest of margins.

How the pandemic alters everything Are we at one of those hinge points in history, like the Great Depression, where the citizenry's political preferences turn in a new direction? To date, we have mostly had to make do with speculation, but two new surveys suggest that there is indeed a big change under way in attitudes.

What can we learn from those at the top? In an uncertain climate, the FT is convening a panel of diverse global leaders to offer insights into their pandemic successes, failures and future plans. For the first instalment, we asked: what is the most significant error you made in the past year, and what is the most significant insight you can share? (FT)

Video of the day

A less damaging way to grow rice? Traditional rice farming consumes up to a third of the world's freshwater supplies and accounts for the same amount of greenhouse gas emissions as the entire aviation industry, pre-pandemic. New strains and farming methods could combat the problem, but convincing farmers and governments remains a challenge. (FT)
